subject: Re: [junit] Re: Categories in JUnit 4.8

messageBody:
I'm with David on being intrigued by the idea of using arbitrary classes. However, I'm much more interested in experiences than in votes. If someone said, "I went through my code and I could definitely use classes as categories because of X, Y and/or Z," would be compelling to me. Even more compelling is if someone would write the test cases for the new scheme.

Regards,

Kent

On Nov 19, 2009, at 7:33 AM, David Saff wrote:

> On Wed, Nov 18, 2009 at 7:46 PM, yme0987654321 <yme0987654321@...> wrote:
> > The decision to use types to define categories is definitely surprising to see, so that has to count against it.
> >
> > However, after the initial shock wears off, I definitely see the power in it, using Java inheritance and static checking rather than free form strings and some arbitrary hierarchy delimiter in the string.
> >
> > However, I think the decision to use a specific new interface as the super type is not a good idea. It would seem you gain the same power by allowing any Class<?>. The advantage of doing this is it would allow real classes within the project to act as Categories, so that if, for example, I am testing a DAO framework, I can categorize individual tests with the specific DAO subclass they are targeting, and then run a category based on the DAO supertype. Much nicer than just calling it all SlowTests. In practice that won't happen often if a custom interface is required because it will introduce a dependency on a JUnit type in the production code.
>
> Huh. The first time through, I thought "that's ridiculous". The
> second time, I wondered if there's not something to this...
>
> Totally musing out loud, but you could rename the annotation as
> TestOf, so that you'd have
>
> @TestOf(CustomStreamingPlatform.class)
>
> Hmm...
>
> > I'm also curious if you considered using an annotation as the category? That is having the category take a Class<?> that represents an annotation? You could support meta-annotations to allow a hierarchy of categories as well as supporting any subclasses or implementations of types so annotated. Coding for that would be nasty business, but it wouldn't be complicated from a client point of view, and would allow the same flexibility of inheritance without the dependency on a JUnit type.
>
> I wanted to stay away from meta-annotations unless the reasons were
> _really_ compelling.
>
> > I would prefer just an arbitrary Class<?>, though. Inheritance is well understood by any Java programmer (unlike meta-annotations) and opens up a synergy between the category hierarchy and the code hierarchy.
>
> Can I get another vote on this extension idea?
>
> David
>
